Posts.Content: I forgot to mention that I also have foot drop as a result of the surgery. I suspect they damaged a nerve to the lower leg.
Posts.Signature: Diagnosed May 2003-- T1a, Biopsy 1of 10 samples positive, prostate 62 grams, PSA 6.3, Gleason (3+4)=7 62 years old at time , 6' 2" - 230# Don't smoke or drink Had LRP at Indiana University Hospital -Indianapolis, In July 1. 2003 Post pathology T2b and negative margins and negative seminal vessels. One set of nerves spared. Partial erections returned after one year plus. Mostly impotent. No leakage after about a year. Surgery lasted 9 1/2 hours resulting in nerve damage to left leg causing foot drop. Standard PSA test with less than on all but three test from Quest. They seem to forget to add the less than carat. Don't worry about it. Had ultra-sensitive test right away the first time and results were negative.
Posts.Title: Swelling in one leg

Posts.Content: Hi Sinister74, I had LRP in 2003 at 62 years od age. I had immediate swelling of the left lower leg and ankle. I usually walk 2 mile three or four days a week and that seems to keep it from swelling. I'm 73 now and restarted golfing last year an recently started riding my bike and not walking. My leg started swelling again. It seems that biking doesn't do the job for me. I guess I need to start walking again. It does tire me a lot but it's better than having the swelling. My swelling usually goes down at night but begins first thing in the morning after standing a while.

Posts.Title: Swelling in one leg

Posts.Content: Deb 27 I had perineural invasion and it's been over 11 years and undetectable. So I wouldn't worry to much about that report. It looks fine to me. Looks like they caught it in time. Ron

Posts.Title: I am worried about these results from final prostate surg/path report:

Posts.Content: Shadowwolf, I think you will be surprised to find that many authorities on the subject have changed their minds after studying the original concept and how one person can affect the entire medical profession views. I've tried to get testosterone for many years but no one will write me a prescript. My level is around 340. I'm thinking if testosterone fuels prostate cancer and my psa is undetectable then I must be cured and should be able to take it after 11 years or my testosterone itself would cause a recurrence. There are doctors prescribing it for some patients. Check out MD Anderson. They are using it for advanced cancer patients and it has brought their psa down to undetectable.
